attributes.title: Protocol for review meditation and attention mechanisms

q1.value: The effects of regular meditation training on attentional control in healthy populations

q3.value: Although the practice of meditation dates back to prehistoric times, relatively little is known about this ancient art, in a scientific context. Recently, research in meditation as a contemplative and neuronal science has developed exponentially, and we are now coming to understand its usefulness in cognitive enhancement. Research in meditation using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), where the use of magnetic fields allow structural differences in the brain to be easily observed; in Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), where brain activity is measured using cerebral blood flow, at a high spatial resolution; and in electroencephalogram (EEG), where brain activity is measured via electric impulses, at a high temporal resolution, demonstrate structural and functional changes in the brain that correlate with these cognitive findings. The mechanism behind meditation in cognitive enhancement is still not yet clearly understood, although a growing body of evidence points to its role in attention regulation as the leading contributor to cognitive gains (Sedlmeier et al., 2012; Chan, Deng, Wu, & Yan, 2019). The purpose of this review is to understand the effectiveness of a regular meditation practice in enhancing attention control in healthy adults. Specifically, improved sustained attention (Badart, McDowall, & Prime, 2018), and selective attention (Blanco, Roca, Duque, Pascual, & Vazquez, 2019) are proposed as the primary components of attention most affected by regular meditation practice.

q4.value:
1) Regular meditation practice enhances attention in healthy populations
2) Regular meditation practice specifically improves sustained attention and selective attention, in healthy populations
3) Enhanced attentional control achieved via regular meditation practice mediates overall cognitive improvement

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The study is a systematic review of the literature. The blinding procedures used in any of the studies finally included for the review, will be noted.

question.value:
Eligibility criteria, study characteristics:
i.	Participants included should be cognitively healthy free from any mental impairments or other medical conditions that may affect cognition and be aged between 18 to 55 years old.
ii.	A previous, recent review and meta-analysis examined the effects of meditation in cognitive enhancement, in general, in the elderly (Chan et al., 2019). Thus, this present review will focus on the effects of meditation, specifically on attention mechanisms, in healthy adults. Targeting this specific demographic, and this particular cognitive domain, serves to further our understanding of the effects of meditation on cognition in an segment where collective research is yet to be synthesised, and to possibly shed light on the mechanisms involved in meditation practice that lead to cognitive enhancement. 
iii.	The study should include an intervention with an explicit meditation or mindfulness practice, be structured and last at least four weeks
iv.	Include at least one weekly guided meditation session or meditation technique instruction class, required for participation
v.	Include a control group, which may be active or waitlisted
vi.	include at least one measure of cognitive attention at baseline and post intervention

Eligibility criteria, report characteristics: Peer reviewed journal articles, dated 2009 onwards, written in English.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

Thus, this present review will focus on the effects of meditation, specifically on attention mechanisms, in healthy adults. Targeting this specific demographic, and this particular cognitive domain, serves to further our understanding of the effects of meditation on cognition in an segment where collective research is yet to be synthesised, and to possibly shed light on the mechanisms involved in meditation practice that lead to cognitive enhancement. 
iii.	The study should include an intervention with an explicit meditation or mindfulness practice, be structured and last at least four weeks
iv.	Include at least one weekly guided meditation session or meditation technique instruction class, required for participation
v.	Include a control group, which may be active or waitlisted
vi.	include at least one measure of cognitive attention at baseline and post intervention

Eligibility criteria, report characteristics: Peer reviewed journal articles, dated 2009 onwards, written in English.

q13.value: Our target sample size is unknown and will depend on the studies which meet the eligibility criteria

question.value: we will primarily measure data sets which include at least one measure of cognitive attention at baseline and post intervention. In addition, for the data sets that meet this criteria, we may also record and interpret the other test scores, if any, of different cognitive measures that are reported at baseline and post intervention.
As this study is a proposed review, there will be no planned statistical analysis of the data

attributes.title: Does Stereotype Threat Predict Support for Gender Balance among Working Adult Women?

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Does Stereotype Threat Predict Support for Gender Balance among Working Adult Women (but not among Men)?

other.value:
I will be including a manipulation check questionnaire item in the online survey to ensure that participants engaged with the stereotype threat recall task correctly. This will be a likert-scale question asking the extent to which participants reflected on a stereotype threat experience in the written reflection task at the beginning of the study. I plan to analyze this item via a t-test analysis with experimental condition (stereotype threat, control) as the IV.

In the demographics section where participants indicate aspects of their workplace, I ask about the perceived gender composition of their level/position as well as the level/position of their superiors. I also ask about how often participants experience stereotype threat at work. These additional items will be included for exploratory purposes, as I suspect they might help us understand and individual/work characteristics that might moderate our focal effect.

sample.value: I aim to recruit at least 200 participants per condition (total N=800 for 2x2 between-subjects experimental design: condition x gender), with over-sampling because I plan to exclude anyone who reports not being employed at least part-time. This goal of N=200 per condition was based on an a priori power analysis conducted using the G*Power software program, calculating the sample size for analyzing the mean difference between two groups with a medium effect size (d = 0.25), alpha = 0.05, and power = 0.8.

analyses.value: I will conduct a 2-way ANOVA to test the significance of the interaction of gender by experimental condition in order to investigate whether women -- but not men -- in the stereotype threat condition (relative to the control condition) are more likely to support gender equality and be more motivated to engage in gender equality initiatives. Specifically, I am looking to see if the condition means for support for gender equality are significantly different for women but not for men.

outliers.value: I plan to exclude any participants who report not being employed either part-time or full-time at the time of data collection; any non-native English speakers; any participants who fail the attention check; and any participants who submit nonsense or gibberish for (or otherwise fail to adequately complete) the writing task that constitutes the experimental manipulation.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is support for gender equality initiatives -- attitudinal support and behavioral support. This will be measured by asking participants (in an online survey) to report how much they support increasing women's representation in leadership positions in their industry (single item, attitudinal support), and how interested they are in investing time and effort into mentoring and advocating on behalf of women and girls for a successful career in their profession (two items, behavioral support).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions: (1) a stereotype threat condition, where participants will be asked to think about a time in the past when they were concerned that their performance at work would be used to gauge their personal abilities and that others would judge them based on their performance; and (2) a control condition, where participants will be asked to recall what they did last Tuesday. All participants will be asked to reflect and write 2-3 sentences about how they felt during these recalled experiences. (This manipulation is based on Shapiro, Williams, & Hambarchyan, 2013.)

hypothesis.value: Does stereotype threat predict support for gender equality initiatives among working adult women, but not among working adult men?

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
